findings.title: Timely updateCumuFundingRate During Pool Liquidity Changes
findings.description: Attackers may make profits by sending multiple transactions in a block to manipulate funding rate and trade.

findings.title: Sandwiched Liquidation To Bypass isQualifiedLiquidator() Check
findings.description: In the Deri protocol, if a trader's margin ratio falls below the maintenance margin ratio, the trader will get liquidated by liquidators. The function check if the parameter, liquidator , is qualified as a liquidator. However, this check can be easily bypassed by sandwiching.

findings.title: Potential Replay Of Signed Prices
findings.description: In the current implementation of the Deri protocol, the `_price` is provided by a trusted oracle. If the oracle is an on-chain contract, `PerpetualPool` can get a price by the oracle’s interface. Conversely, if the oracle is an EOA account, `PerpetualPool` should check the price signature first to verify if the price is authorized.

findings.title: Potential Front-Running For setPool()
findings.description: Front-running issue in the `setPool()` routine allowing anyone to call the function and set an arbitrary pool address to the token.

findings.title: Lack Of Sanity Checks For System Parameters
findings.description: DeFi protocols typically have a number of system-wide parameters that can be dynamically configured on demand. The Deri protocol is no exception. Specifically, if we examine the `PerpetualPool` contract, it has defined a number of system-wide risk parameters, e.g., `_redemptionFeeRatio`, `_minMaintenanceMarginRatio`, and `_minLiquidationReward`. In the following, we show the `initialize()` routine that sets up these parameters.

findings.title: Incompatibility with Deflationary/Rebasing Tokens
findings.description: The PerpetualPool contract's asset-transferring routines may not work as expected with deflationary or rebasing tokens that charge a fee for every transfer() or transferFrom().
